content: How can I help you today?

Honestly, I’m not sure if this will help, but my wife insisted I come. We’ve been dealing with a lot at home, especially with my son’s behavior. It’s been overwhelming, and it’s starting to affect everything, including my marriage. I don’t even know where to start.

It sounds like things have been really overwhelming for you lately, especially with everything happening at home with your son and how it’s impacting your marriage. That must be a lot to carry. What’s been the most challenging part of it all for you?

I think it's just the feeling of not knowing how to help my son. My wife and I have tried so much, but nothing seems to work, and it's causing tension between us. It feels like I'm failing as a father and a husband, and the weight of that is just… heavy.

That sounds incredibly heavy, and it means a lot that you’re sharing this. It’s clear how much you care about your son and your family—you’ve been trying so hard, which speaks to your commitment as a father and husband. Feeling like you’re not getting anywhere, despite all your efforts, must be deeply frustrating and painful. What do you think makes this situation feel so stuck right now?

I think it just feels like no matter what we try, nothing changes. My son keeps acting out, and my wife and I end up arguing about how to handle things. It’s like we’re on different pages, and it’s hard not to feel like we’re just failing as a team. That, on top of everything else in life, makes it really hard to see a way forward.

It sounds like you’ve been caught in this cycle where things feel stuck, no matter how hard you try, and that’s adding strain not only to your relationship with your son but also with your wife. It’s like you’re carrying so much already, and the lack of progress and connection as a team makes it even harder to move forward. Do you feel like there’s anything you’ve tried in the past, either with your son or with your wife, that felt even a little helpful, even if it didn’t solve everything?

Honestly, nothing really stands out. We’ve tried grounding him, giving him more attention, even seeing if there’s something at school causing this, but nothing seems to stick. With my wife, we’ve tried talking it out, but those conversations always turn into arguments, so it feels like we’re going in circles.

It sounds like you and your wife have been making a real effort to address things, both with your son and with each other. Even though it feels like you’re going in circles, the fact that you've both kept trying really shows your dedication to your family. It must be exhausting though, to feel like you’re putting in so much and not seeing the results you hope for. How do you keep yourself going through all of this?

Honestly, I don’t know. Most days I just feel drained, and I’m not sure how I keep pushing forward. I guess I just do because I don’t have a choice. It’s for my family, you know? But I can’t say I feel like I’m doing a good job of it.

It sounds like you’re running on empty, but you keep going because your family means so much to you. That takes a lot of strength, even if it doesn’t feel that way right now. The fact that you’re here today also shows how much you care and want things to be better, even if it feels like you’re not sure where to start. What do you think would ease some of the weight you’re feeling right now?

Honestly, I think just feeling like there’s a plan or even knowing what to do next would help. Right now, everything feels so out of control, and I don't even know where to begin. Having some kind of direction—just something to make me feel like I’m not failing—might make it all a little less heavy.

Having a clear direction could definitely make things feel more manageable, especially when everything feels so overwhelming. It sounds like you’re really wanting to feel more in control and to know that the steps you’re taking are making a difference for your family. Before we think ahead, is there anything else about what you’re experiencing that feels important to share?

I think that covers most of it. It’s really just this constant stress at home with my son and the strain it’s putting on my marriage. I don’t know how to help him or fix things with my wife, and it’s affecting everything else—work, my mood, even time with my daughter. It all just feels like too much.

Thank you for sharing all of that. You're balancing so many heavy emotions—stress from home, a strained relationship with your wife, feeling unsure about helping your son, and how it’s rippling into other parts of your life, even affecting your time with your daughter. That’s so much to carry, and it’s understandable that it feels like too much. It also shows how deeply you care about your family and their well-being.  

Would it feel okay to start a conversation about where you’d like to focus first and what that direction might look like for you? Or is there anything else you'd like to touch on before thinking about next steps?

I think focusing on a direction might help, even if it’s just a small step. I’m not sure where to start, but I know I need to do something—for my son, my wife, and even myself. What do you think might be a good first step?

It's good to hear you're open to taking a small step forward—it sounds like you're ready to start exploring ways to lighten this load you're carrying. Before suggesting anything, it's important to make sure that we focus on what feels right for you.  

From everything you've shared, it seems like you're looking for clarity and ways to feel more in control. What would you say feels most important to focus on first? Is it addressing things with your son, working on communication with your wife, or even finding ways to support yourself so you have the energy to keep moving forward?

I think focusing on my son might be the most urgent. I feel like if we could figure out what’s going on with him and help him, maybe some of the stress on my wife and me would ease. But I also need to support myself better—I just don’t know how to balance it all. What do you think?

It sounds like focusing on your son feels like the most pressing issue for you right now, and you’re aware that supporting yourself is also important in order to handle everything else. That’s a lot of insight you're bringing forward.  

It might help to take that first step by exploring what’s going on with your son in a way that keeps the lines of communication open with him and with your wife. At the same time, balancing that with something small, something manageable, to support your own well-being could make this feel less overwhelming.  

Would it feel helpful to explore some possibilities for how you could approach understanding and supporting your son, while also finding ways to care for yourself along the way? Or is there a specific area with your son’s behavior where you already feel like you want to start?

I think looking at some options for understanding and supporting my son could help. Honestly, I’m not sure where to start with him, but maybe just understanding why he’s acting out would be a good place. I feel like once we figure that out, we might be able to come up with a plan. As for me, I don’t even know what it means to care for myself right now, but I’d be open to hearing ideas.

That sounds like a thoughtful place to begin—focusing on understanding what might be behind your son’s behavior could help you feel more confident about the next steps. It’s also great to hear you’re open to considering ways to care for yourself, even if it feels unclear right now.  

Would it feel helpful to explore ways to better connect with your son, maybe through open communication or observing what might be triggering his behavior? And for yourself, starting small—like identifying one thing that helps you de-stress or recharge—could be a gentle way to begin. How does that sound to you?
